title: Oppression and Deliverance
objective: Connect exodus event to covenant faithfulness

required_passages.text: And it came to pass in process of time, that the king of Egypt died: and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up unto God by reason of the bondage. And God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob. And God looked upon the children of Israel, and God had respect unto them.

segments.audio_script: This is lesson nine. You are studying oppression and deliverance. Lesson eight completed the Genesis unit on covenant structure.

And it came to pass in process of time, that the king of Egypt died: and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up unto God by reason of the bondage. And God heard their groaning, and God remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob. And God looked upon the children of Israel, and God had respect unto them.
Israel experiences oppression in Egypt. Generations pass. God hears their cry and remembers covenant with Abraham. Deliverance is covenant memory—God acts to fulfill ancient promises.
Exodus 6 explicitly connects deliverance to Abrahamic covenant. God promises to bring Israel out through mighty acts. Land is gift not earned. Deliverance manifests covenant faithfulness.
Key themes: redemption means divine rescue from bondage. Covenant memory means God recalls and acts on previous commitments. Exodus is redemptive event establishing Israel as covenant people.
What does God remember when Israel cries out from oppression?
This completes lesson nine. You studied oppression and deliverance. Next lesson examines the Passover and substitutionary themes.

vocabulary.definition: Divine rescue from bondage effected through God's covenant faithfulness
God's recall and fulfillment of previous covenant commitments

study_notes: The exodus demonstrates that covenant is not abandoned despite delay. God's faithfulness persists through generations and manifests through redemptive acts.
